title: 107_hr3323
content: The Act may be cited as the "Administrative Simplification Compliance Act" and extends the deadline for covered entities to submit compliance plans. The "Administrative Simplification Compliance Act" extends the deadline for covered entities to comply with certain regulations until October 16, 2003, if a compliance plan is submitted to the Secretary of Health and Human Services before October 16, 2002. The compliance plan must include an analysis of non-compliance, a budget, schedule, and implementation strategy for achieving compliance, potential use of contractors, and a testing timeframe starting by April 16, 2003. Plans can be submitted electronically, and a model form will be provided by the Secretary of Health and Human Services by March 31, 2002. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide the National Committee on Vital and Health Statistics with sample plans for analysis. The Committee will then publish reports with effective solutions to compliance problems identified in the plans. The National Committee on Vital and Health Statistics will consult with relevant organizations to provide effective solutions for compliance problems identified in sample plans. Confidential information will be protected during this process. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will redact any material provided to the National Committee on Vital and Health Statistics to protect confidential information. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will redact any material provided to the National Committee on Vital and Health Statistics to protect confidential information, including trade secrets, privileged commercial or financial information, and personal privacy. Enforcement through exclusion from participation in Medicare for non-compliance with submission requirements and regulations. Exclusion at the discretion of the Secretary of Health and Human Services from participation in Medicare programs. The exclusion from participation in Medicare for non-compliance with submission requirements and regulations is enforced through section 1128A of the Social Security Act. This exclusion does not affect the imposition of penalties under section 1176 of the Act and does not apply to complying persons. The exclusion from Medicare for non-compliance with submission requirements and regulations is enforced through section 1128A of the Social Security Act. This exclusion does not affect penalties under section 1176 and does not apply to those who submit a plan or comply with specific regulations by October 16, 2002. Special rules clarify deadlines for compliance with certain regulations. During the period from April 14, 2003, to October 16, 2003, health care providers and clearinghouses transmitting electronic health information must comply with privacy standards regardless of meeting transaction standards. During the specified period, entities processing health care information must comply with privacy standards, including health care claims transactions. Entities processing health care information must comply with privacy standards, including various types of transactions such as health care payment, coordination of benefits, claim status, enrollment, eligibility, premium payments, and referral authorization. Definitions of terms like "health care provider", "health plan", and "health care clearinghouse" are provided in relevant regulations. The terms related to different health care transactions are defined in section 160.103 and sections 162.1101, 162.1601, 162.1801, 162.1401, 162.1501, 162.1201, 162.1701, and 162.1301 of title 45, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. REQUIRING ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION OF MEDICARE CLAIMS. Section 1862 of the Social Security Act is amended to require electronic submission of Medicare claims, with exceptions for cases where electronic submission is not possible or for small providers. The Social Security Act is amended to require electronic submission of Medicare claims, with exceptions for small providers with fewer than 25 full-time equivalent employees for services or suppliers, effective for claims submitted on or after October 16, 2003. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to include Medicare+Choice organizations under administrative simplification requirements. SEC. 5 authorizes appropriations for implementing regulations. Authorized appropriations of $44,200,000 for technical assistance, education, outreach, and enforcement activities related to specific regulations. Reductions in funding if model form deadlines are not met. If the Secretary fails to promulgate the model form within 30 days after the deadline, the funding will be reduced by 50%. If the deadline is missed by 45 days, the reduction will be 75%, and if it's missed by 60 days, the reduction will be 100%.
